instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:
Hi,
this board is clean no liquid spill, the customer say, the mac make beep memory after an install system.
Now I have just fan spin, no chime and no display. i make this measure:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.8v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3,4v
<SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0,8V???
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.23v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.34v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1,7V
<SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL>=3,4V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL> seems not good no?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:
Calculating <RESISTOR>R0620</RESISTOR>/21 resistor divider, <SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL> looks good.

What about <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> = 3,41V
i don't find the signal <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> because my board file is not the same like <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.
do you have the good brd file? where can find it? on vinafix is not good.
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:
Not real schematic/boardview files for this board; only 00163 available.

"i don't find the signal <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>"
Only one 0 ohm resistor present on pin 5/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>; no boardview needed.
Just check if that resistor is good.

What about <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> = <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>/pin 5 = 3,4V <RESISTOR>R1947</RESISTOR> is good 0ohm

<SIGNAL>XDP_CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0V on <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>, maybe <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> but can't find it
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCST</SIGNAL> = 1,05V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0V, <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCST</SIGNAL>=1,05V, <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>= 0V
<CHIP>U1100</CHIP> is dead?
i don't understand if it's <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> who make the <SIGNAL>CPU_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal or <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> for <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
can i jump <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> to 1,05V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1930</CHIP> must translate 3V from <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> to 1V at <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
If <RESISTOR>R1930</RESISTOR> is good, change <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message: where is it? In the boardview of <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, <RESISTOR>R1930</RESISTOR> & <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> is not present.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan start, no chime, no display
threads.message:

I can't find <RESISTOR>R1930</RESISTOR> :-(
